diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.
mortality rate: 25% within 15 years of diagnosis
treatment: Immunosuppressive medications and anti-inflammatory drugs
risk factors: Family history, certain medications, ultraviolet light, viruses
description: A chronic inflammatory disease characterized by oral ulcers, genital ulcers, eye inflammation (uveitis), and skin lesions.
prevalence: 0.1-300 cases per 100,000 people, highest in Mediterranean and Middle Eastern countries
mortality rate: Low, but complications like eye damage or venous thrombosis can be life-threatening
treatment: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and biological response modifiers
risk factors: Genetic and environmental factors
description: A disorder in which the bodys immune system destroys its own red blood cells, leading to anemia.
mortality rate: Varies depending on the underlying cause and severity, can be life-threatening if left untreated
risk factors: Autoimmune diseases (such as lupus erythematosus or Sjögrens syndrome), medications, certain infections
description: An infection with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causing fever, fatigue, sore throat, and a mononucleocytosis.
prevalence: 45% among adults aged 35 and over have been infected
mortality rate: Rare, can occur in very young or older individuals and those with compromised immune systems
treatment: Supportive care, antiviral therapy (e.g., acyclovir)
risk factors: Contact with the infected saliva or fluids
description: A severe and potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications.
prevalence: Rare, estimated between 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 10,000 exposures to the culprit drug
treatment: Discontinue the causative medication, corticosteroids, supportive care
risk factors: Susceptibility and specific medications like antiepileptics, allopurinol, minocycline
description: A severe skin reaction associated with the antipsychotic medication quetiapine (Seroquel)
prevalence: Estimated at 10.3 cases per 10,000 patient-years
mortality rate: Up to 37%, depending on the severity and complications
treatment: Immediate withdrawal of Seroquel, supportive treatment, corticosteroids, cyclosporine
risk factors: Use of Seroquel for longer than one month or with dosage above 300mg per day
description: A life-threatening skin reaction characterized by widespread epidermal detachment
prevalence: 0.4-1.2 cases per million population per year

mortality rate: 25-35%
      treatment: Specialized burn unit, intravenous immunotherapy, supportive measures
risk factors: Medications like antibiotics (sulfonamides) and antiepileptics
symptoms: Fever, widespread rash that progresses to skin peeling
description: Inflammation of blood vessels as an immune response to a trigger like a medication
prevalence: Varies depending on the cause
mortality rate: Up to 33%, highly variable depending on the severity and organ systems involved
treatment: Identify and remove the trigger and administer corticosteroids or other immunomodulator therapies
risk factors: Medications and infections being the common culprits
description: Cancers affecting bone marrow leading to high numbers of immature or abnormal white blood cells
mortality rate: Without appropriate treatment, up to 99%, depends on the subtype and age
treatment: Intense chemotherapy or targeted therapies (for some subtypes like acute promyelocytic leukemia or Philadelphia-positive acute lymphocytic leukemia)
risk factors: Mutations in blood cells or environmental triggers
description: Infection with Human Immunodeficiency Virus attacking and weakening the immune system
treatment: Combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) reduces viral load and improves the health of the immune system
risk factors: Unprotected sexual intercourse, needle sharing by IV drug users

symptoms: Flu-like illness and swollen lymph nodes in an initial acute phase; in chronic phase - opportunistic illnesses like pneumocystis pneumonia or wasting disorder or oral candidiasis (thrush)

description: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect the lining of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus. It causes inflammation, which can lead to abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
